Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Three straight sessions of gains sent both the S&P 500 and the DJIA up to the top of the up channel started in June. The afternoon retreat suggested momentum wasn't very strong. With stocks overbought, expect a near term pullback which could become a buying opportunity, as the central bankers look to be gearing (as least talking) up for more QEs. Technically, both the small cap Russell 2000 and mid cap S&P 400 broke out above their downtrend started in July today, suggesting a potential change of their intermediate trend to up. With that said, there are many unresolved negative divergences between the price levels of the major indexes and their technical indicators as well as the market internal readings. Stay nimble and be cautious. have a nice day.

I do know what you are asking and I'm sorry to say that I don't have enough of a technical background to give the exact answer. Intel has been offering a motherboard without a video card for years. It wasn't until a half generation before Sandy Bridge that they started offering a viable solution. They were able to play 1080P video and do a reasonably good job with games. The internal GPU was good enough to take on the sub-$150 video card market. For a good portion of the market this was good enough. To a real gamer, this is never good enough because they are into much higher end graphics. What you are asking is if in a few years can you change out your GPU and CPU. I was under the impression with Sandy Bridge that the GPU was in part under the die of the CPU. The other thing that you may have not taken into consideration is that the motherboard changes as well over time. It can take on more RAM and faster ram, offer new ports such as SATA 6 and Thunderbolt. When your CPU starts to get technically obsolete chances are that there would have been so many improvements in the motherboard technology that you will want a new motherboard as well.

Technical reasons aren't holding back your dream: "If INTC bought NVDA, then could they incorporate the tech into the motherboard?" INTC kicked NVDA off the motherboard... Now INTC pays NVDA $1.5B for contract violation...

Topic.Title: Yes we all know our nation is screwed.

Message.Msg: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the future but voters do not seem to be holding it against Democratic President Barack Obama, who slightly expanded his lead over Republican rival Mitt Romney this month, a new Reuters/Ipsos poll says. Three months before the November 6 presidential election, nearly two-thirds of Americans think the country is moving in the wrong direction. Only 31 percent say it is moving in the right direction - the lowest number since December 2011. But Obama's lead over Romney among registered voters was 49 percent to 42 percent, up slightly from the 6-point advantage the president held a month earlier over the former Massachusetts governor.

Message.Title: Traditional Model of Funding Semiconductor Equipment is Broken?
Message.Msg: At Semicon a few weeks ago the big news was that Intel was making a big investment in ASML as a way of funding two development programs: extreme ultra-violet (EUV) and 450mm wafers. This week TSMC announced that they would join the program too, committing 275M Euros over a five year period. They are also taking a 5% stake in ASML. ASML have said that they are also talking to some other smaller vendors....... http://www.semiwiki.com/forum/content/1558-traditional-model-funding-semiconductor-equipment-broken.html By Dr. Paul McLellan
think INTC is starting rise rise on these rumores and AAPL's announcement in early September

Well, the enterprise power users who may use Macros and other complex features will find Windows RT unacceptable. But on a more basic level, I think even users who may be able to live with Office RT will find that the Tablet form factor is not optimal for their basic word processing / spreadsheet tasks. I can't imagine typing a bunch of stuff on a virtual keyboard or on the flimsy keyboard on the Surface Tablet cover. And if you keep needing to hook up a real keyboard/mouse, you may as well go with a touch-based or hybrid laptop. I think the Tablet is primarily an entertainment device and may be ok for a few FB postings. But not for doing word processing or spreadsheets. Those who think that Office is a compelling offering for Surface are going to be disappointed - Apple iPad and Google Nexus cover both the premium and value sides of the market, Surface may end up being another Zune/Kin for Microsoft.
Defend your shareholders Paul O. You can't let this garbage go out! What are you thinking? This is going to destroy your WART business!

Topic.Title: Motorola and Intel hold hands for multi-year, multi-device partnership, shipments start 2H 2012

Message.Msg: I heard all the Motorola smartphones will have Intel inside by year end. Only on one of the many articles that I read, it said that all will be Intel based. I too am anxiously waiting to get one. It's gotta be better than anything else in performance I'm sure. With the backing of Google, I'm sure customers will get serious support. Google has lots and lots of money to invest in this thing.

This is bad news for Apple. Each lost phone sales is a lost ecosystem sale. The iPods now their iPhones were the gateway into the Apple Universe. The article said that the phone sales came at the expense of RIMM and other small players. Sure, today it's not worth it to contract for a phone with an OS that may not be around in a couple of years when the phone contract is finished. The BS we heard from Apple was that consumers were waiting for the new iPhone. What we saw was that the market was in fact growing and Apple has sold more iPhones year over year. The problem is that Android is growing four times faster. What this means is that new customers were more likely not to buy the iPhone. You will see this trend happen with the iPad as well in the next couple of years. Keep in mind that 80% of Apple's profits are based on those two ARM based products. What can we learn from this? 1. Consumers aren't as likely to buy an iPhone because it has an Apple logo on it as they used to be. 2. iPhone gets new models once a year, Android at least every month. This raises the bar faster than Apple can respond. 3. The modified ARM processor isn't unique enough for Apple to have a have a selling feature that stands out over the competition. Consumers don't know of the A5 processor or why they should buy it over a Tegra3. All they know is that they found Samsung phones that are better fits for them.

This would be an win/win for Apple and Intel. Apple to me these days strikes me as a company that is in the "don't rock the boat" phase of their existence. Long term strategic moves seems like something that they aren't good at any longer. I would love this rumor to be true, but I am skeptical.
